Award.AwardTitle: Improved Human-Computer Interaction for Design of Complex Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Future design of complex systems, for example, the design of aircraft, buildings, and transportation systems, will be done collaboratively by mixed teams of humans and artificial intelligence (AI) systems. The success of this collaboration depends on the degree to which the humans and the AI systems can effectively communicate with each other their goals, intentions and plans of actions. This award seeks to improve how humans and AI systems communicate when designing such systems. In particular, the investigators will give intelligent design agents the ability to provide explanations of their actions and suggestions to humans through both verbal and non-verbal communication channels. It also investigates how the AI system can use robotic body language to improve the collaborative design process. This has potential to have an impact on many aspects of our society which engage in system design, including architecture, medicine, urban planning, industrial design, and business management. Additionally, the research project provides opportunities for education and outreach during its execution.

The research objective of this award is to enable mixed-initiative human-computer design of complex systems by giving intelligent design agents self-explaining abilities, modeling human-computer joint design as a collaborative activity, and leveraging the use of non-verbal channels and embodied interaction to improve human-machine communication in design. Starting from a model of design tools as intelligent agents, and based on the knowledge generated by the Human-Robot Collaboration literature, we will lay out the foundations of a new paradigm for engineering design based on mixed-initiative human-agent collaboration. The four pillars of this new paradigm are: (a) the coordination and meshing of shared plans and intentions between humans and design agents, and their resolution into individual agent plans and actions; (b) the dynamic allocation of roles and gradation of autonomy; (c) the reasoning about, generation, and maintenance of shared attention and common ground; and (d) the integration of verbal and nonverbal channels in communication about agent beliefs, intentions, and goals. Controlled experiments with human subjects will be used to test the effectiveness of the new framework and algorithms. If successful, this research can radically improve the quality of the designs and reduce the resources spent during the design process of complex engineering systems of national importance and high value to society such as systems-of-systems for weather forecasting, climate monitoring, disaster relief, or intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance. This research will also have broader impacts into areas outside of engineering that engage in system design activities, including architecture, medicine, urban planning, industrial design, and business management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied foundational questions related to how humans and AI systems can work together on the design of complex systems. We did so primarily by developing new models for AI systems that can aid human designers. For example, we structured the design task as a collaborative activity, rather than as a situation where a human designer asks an expert system, treating it like a passive tool. To enable a collaborative AI designer, we also studied ways to give these AI systems self-explaining abilities. For example, the AI could explain why it made a certain suggestion, or describe how it saw the current state of the design process.

We also explored new roles for AI design assistants. One such role is that of an “analyst,” performing database searches and data mining related to the design problem. Another role is that of a “critic”. An AI critic can list strengths and weaknesses of a human-proposed design by combining information from heuristics obtained directly from experts or extracted from databases using machine learning.  

This project also focused on an additional aspect of human-AI collaborative design, one that has rarely - if ever - been studied before. In contrast to prior work, our experiments moved the design task out of the screen and into the physical world. This mirrors what many human design teams do, when they use scale models, pin-up renderings, and physical prototypes. One of the reasons for this choice was to enable the AI design assistant to make use of the benefits of full-body collaboration. To achieve this, we developed an instrumented sand-table where the AI system could track the physical design decisions that the human did. We also added a robotic design assistant. The robot co-manipulated the physical design objects with the human to try to achieve better solutions. 

The project supported a number of empirical human-participant studies evaluating the benefits and challenges of a human-AI and human-robot collaborative design team. Through these studies, we learned, for example, that humans vary greatly in how they approach the design problem and the AI collaborator. Some designers were top-down comprehensive thinkers while others were bottom-up exploratory tinkerers. An AI system needs to take these styles into account to provide the best support. Furthermore, we found that people take different roles vis-a-vis the robotic assistant, with some seeing the robot as a subordinate and others seeing it as an export. Finally, we found that even the most pragmatic actions on the robot’s part were imbued with social and psychological meaning by human designers.  All of these lead to implications for using such design assistants in the real world.

In other studies, which included both professional and novice designers, we found that using an AI design agent significantly improved the quality of the designs generated. Somewhat worryingly, we also found a negative influence of the AI collaborator. In some cases, the use of the design assistant caused participants to explore less diverse solutions and also to learn less in the process of working on the problem. Through a large set of interrelated studies, we also learned about the difficulties of measuring how much humans learn in these kinds of problems. Finally, we uncovered insights about how different cognitive and learning styles affect the collaborative design process, an important aspect that future systems will need to take into account. 

As part of the above-mentioned studies, we developed numerous design domain models, simulators, and AI algorithms to support design tasks. These will serve as the foundation for future research to build better assistants for human designers. 

However, the potential impact of this work is broader than just engineering design. The AI methods and insights developed in this project could be used to support a large number of decision-making tasks. Keeping in mind that research, design, and decision-making make up some of the most productive and important sectors supporting the strength of the US economy, we believe that our work can help make these sectors even more productive. This has potential to have a large impact on the many aspects of our society which engage in system design and decision-making, including architecture, medicine, urban planning, politics, industrial design, and business management.
